title: ‘History is repeating itself’: fight against far-right in London’s East End goes on
summary: It was 89 years ago this month that local people drove out Oswald Mosley’s Blackshirt militia from Whitechapel in the East End, in what has become known as the Battle of Cable Street. In the decades since, the National Front, the BNP and the English Defence League have all tried to carve out a foothold in the area. In 2025, communities are fighting back against the hard right yet again. This week, police stopped the hard-right UK Independence Party (Ukip) from staging a “crusade on White chapel” in the borough of Tower Hamlets. The Metropolitan police said the ban was to prevent “serious disorder” It comes weeks after Tower Hamlet council passed a motion that said flags were “important emblems of patriotism and pride”, but condemned “outside far-right agitators … attempting to import division into our borough,” particularly on the Isle of Dogs.

title: Support for Reform UK increasing among British Indians, poll shows
summary: Research by 1928 Institute shows backing for Reform has jumped from 4% to 13%. British Indians, who form about 3% of the population, are becoming increasingly important swing voters. At the last election 48% of British Indians voted for Labour, 21% for the Conservatives and only 4% for Reform. Now, however, Labour support stands at 35% with the Indian community, while the Conservatives have collapsed to 18%. Support for the Greens has also risen sharply, especially among younger voters, going from 8% at the election to 13% now. Research shows the shift is being driven in part by changing policy priorities. While Indian voters always put education at the top of their concerns, their second priority has changed from health to the economy now. Their third priority is crime, having been the environment five years ago. Equalities and human rights has dropped from fifth on the list of priorities to seventh.

title: We are heartbroken after synagogue attack, says senior UK Jewish politician
summary: Richard Hermer said tackling rising tide of antisemitism would require police protection and political leaders calling it out wherever it was found. The attorney general is a close ally of Keir Starmer in cabinet. Starmer issued a message to Jewish people on Thursday night pledging to ‘wrap arms’ around the community in the wake of the attack. He said: “I know how much fear you will be holding inside of you. I really do … Nobody should have to do that. Nobody’s.” Starmer, whose wife, Victoria, is Jewish, made tackling antisemitic in Labour a major priority after he became party leader.

title: Drag acts, detractors and true-blue diehards: my weird weekend at a Margaret Thatcher festival
summary: The bronze statue of Margaret Thatcher by the sculptor Douglas Jennings has a rating of 2.8 out of five on Google Maps. The statue was originally commissioned more than a decade ago, and was intended to stand in front of the Houses of Parliament. Westminster city council rejected it on the grounds that it might become a target for vandalism. Instead, it was offered to her birthplace of Grantham, a town she left at the age of 18 and rarely visited again. The presence of Thatcher in her home town, on what would have been her 100th birthday, has drawn a small crowd outside the town’s Guildhall Arts Centre. Motorists toot horns; fans want selfies; passersby occasionally flick V-signs from across the street. Somehow it scarcely matters that the figure they are venerating and vilifying is not Thatcher at all, but an actor named Matt Tedford, who plays the former prime minister in a riotous drag show called Margaret Thatcher: Queen of Soho.

title: For some minority Britons the ‘unite the kingdom’ rally shows far-right politics is becoming legitimised
summary: Hetticia McIntosh, 70, from Manchester, was warned by a WhatsApp “community safety alert”, to “avoid travelling into London … especially if you are from an ethnic minority” “I remember my father marching against the National Front in the 1970s. It felt like it was a minority. The majority of people are still decent. But now, the far right seems legitimised and popular,” Dabinderjit Singh, a retired senior civil servant said. McIntosh knows exactly where racist sentiment can lead. The Home Office inexplicably refused to renew her and her husband’s British passports in the 70s and 1980s, forcing them to leave the country for St Lucia for decades. She now fears, amid talk of “remigration” from the far-right, hardening attitudes to legal migration in Westminster and a government struggling to convey a positive message of unity, that “another Windrush scandal’ could happen.

title: Reform UK council removes St George and union flags over safety fears
summary: Durham county council has started to remove flags and bunting displaying the St George’s cross and the union flag. The council said it had been “left with no choice but to remove bunting” after a risk assessment found that “rope involved was so strong that, had a high-sided vehicle driven into it, the poles it was attached to could have been pulled down” In the past few weeks there has been increasing controversy over the number of flags being flown in towns across England. Some say it is simply a show of national pride and patriotism, while others argue the swell of interest in flying flags is linked to the far right and anti-migrant sentiment. The topic has attracted comment and debate beyond Britain, with the tech mogul and outspoken Reform UK supporter Elon Musk posting a St George's cross to his X feed.

title: UK charities say toxic immigration rhetoric leading to threats against staff
summary: Voluntary organisations say they are being forced to introduce extensive security measures to protect staff and property. Incidents include threats to rape and kill staff, verbal and physical abuse of beneficiaries on the street, attempted break-ins to charity-owned accommodation, and damage to offices and vandalism. A coalition of more than 150 charities has written to the prime minister, Keir Starmer, urging him to challenge the “cynical” targeting of civil society organisations by far-right politicians and activists. One charity chief executive told the Guardian increasingly mainstream political rhetoric on the political right denigrating immigrants and refugees had created a “permission structure” for racism. A government spokesperson said: “Racism is completely unacceptable and has no place in our society.”

title: Starmer will hand Britain over to Farage, says Green party leader Zack Polanski
summary: Polanski condemned what he called Labour’s ‘managed decline’ and the aping of Reform policies in areas such as migration. He expressed his horror at the attack on a synagogue in the city on Thursday and made a strong defence of migration. “I’m one of five Jewish people to lead a British political party in the last 100 years,” he said. Green membership has risen to more than 80,000 for the first time. Polanski won an overwhelming 85% of the membership vote against a joint bid by two MPs, Adrian Ramsay and Ellie Chowns, to lead the party in England and Wales. He said: “Everything we do between now and the next election must be bold. Boldness means connecting with how hard it is right now for so many people.”

title: ‘I refuse to be defined by fascism’: daughter of murder victim speaks after death of neo-Nazi killer in prison
summary: Pavlo Lapshyn was found dead in his cell at Wakefield prison on Tuesday. The circumstances of his death have not yet been publicly confirmed. He was convicted at the Old Bailey in October 2013 of murdering Muslim man Mohammed Saleem, 82, in April of that year. Saleem was a pillar of the local community who was on his way home from evening prayers at the mosque when he was stabbed three times in the back and stamped on his head. He later planted three bombs outside mosques in Walsall, Wolverhampton and Tipton. Along with Saleem’s murder, he was convicted of causing an explosion with intent to endanger life and of engaging in conduct in preparation of terrorist acts. A picture found on his computer by police had words and images relating to the murder, with a smiley face and the slogan “WHITE POWER”

title: Jeremy Corbyn to appear in north London panto
summary: Islington North MP will perform as the ‘Wizard of Oz-lington’ in a drag production of Wicked Witches. The venue said he would make an onscreen cameo. “The Pleasance [theatre] has been at the heart of our community for 30 years, and local theatre like this deserves our support,” he said. The theatre said: “His cameo adds a touch of local sparkle to our wickedly funny festive panto’s first in over 20 years and raises the curtain on our 30th anniversary celebrations”

title: Keir Starmer calls student protests on 7 October anniversary ‘un-British’
summary: Keir Starmer has urged students not to protest on the second anniversary of the Hamas-led 7 October attacks on Israel. The prime minister said protests due to take place at universities on Tuesday showed a lack of respect for others. He added that the pro-Palestine protests had been used by some as a “despicable excuse to attack British Jews’ Hamas militants killed about 1,200 people and took 251 hostages during an assault on southern Israel on 7 October 2023. Israel’s subsequent offensive has so far killed more than 67,000 Palestinians and wounded about 170,000, according to the Gaza health ministry. Thousands of people attended an event in Trafalgar Square in central London on Sunday to mark the two-year anniversary. The shadow justice secretary, Robert Jenrick, called plans for protests in towns and cities including London, Manchester, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Bristol “a fucking disgrace”

title: Sidekick Starmer can’t get a word in as The Donald dominates world’s most one-sided double act
summary: The US president is like a radio presenter on the graveyard night-time slot. Filling the dead air with a long rambling stream of unconsciousness. Needy – greedy – for any attention he can get. No longer just the most important person in his own life but the most. important person on the planet. Europe was in a bad place. Almost unrecognisable from the Europe of 10 years ago. Too many foreigners. He didn’t know anything about the small boat crossings, he admitted, but he was still sure they were all rapists and murderers. Yes, he did think people were starving in Gaza and Israel would have to allow more aid in. He seemed to want thanks for sending food, rather than seeing it as a legal and moral obligation. Putin had disappointed him. He was going to have to rethink his 50 days. And it was time to acknowledge the six wars he had stopped. Almost one a month. He sounded as if he was nominating himself for the Nobel peace prize.

title: Reform wheels out Danny Kruger, the ‘brains’ of Nigel Farage’s operation
summary: Danny Kruger is the latest Reform recruit, having jumped ship from the Tories. Since transferring his affections to Farage, Kruger has been entrusted with getting Reform policy ready for the next election. He is presented to the world as a man with experience of government. Only in reality he has none. All he has ever done is write a few speeches for David Cameron while in opposition and act as Boris Johnson’s political secretary for a couple of months in 2019. He has no more inside knowledge than the rest of us. What could possibly go wrong? Confused? You soon will be. For their second press conference in as many days, Reform let Kruger loose, closely policed by Zia Yusuf. He was feeling chipper, he began. Thrilled to be free. Reform was currently like an unruly pirate ship but give it a few years and it would be a fully functioning naval vessel. Or not. Nige has had years and years of running political parties, and they have never evolved much beyond a one-man band. But this time would be different. Reform promised to be the grownups. Serious times required serious politicians.

title: Families of David Amess and Jo Cox voice concern at rise in violent political rhetoric
summary: Families of murdered MPs David Amess and Jo Cox have voiced concern about a recent surge in violent political rhetoric in Britain. There are also concerns over an increasing normalisation of language calling for political figures to be killed. Examples include the suspension of a Reform UK councillor linked to a social media account calling for Keir Starmer to be shot. A man allegedly captured on film at major far-right rally last month in London threatening to kill the prime minister. At the same rally, Elon Musk made comments that later drew condemnation from Downing Street when he told the crowd that “violence is coming” The language comes after a summer of anti-immigration protests, culture war flashpoints and a surge in podcasts and YouTube videos predicting civil war. Katie Amess said the murder of rightwing activist Charlie Kirk had been a triggering moment for her family but should also come as a wake-up call.

title: Kemi Badenoch says she is ‘doing politics differently’ – you can’t argue with that
summary: Kemi Badenoch was a guest on Laura Kuenssberg's TV show on Sunday. She was talking about her plans to deport 150,000 people a year and leave the European convention on human rights. But it quickly dawned on Laura that she was dealing with an idiot. The 2024 general election a high point in her party’s fortunes. Her personal ratings in freefall. She and her party a mere sideshow. Mainly interesting for how much worse they can get. The clue was in the title in Europe were not the US and Canada were not in Europe. We did not get to talk about the ECHR. We never got to discuss the US or Canada leaving the European Convention on Human Rights. In any case, Italy was trying to change it from Good Friday to Good Friday. That was different from the way Kemi was leaving it. She has never really quite got a grip on the interview format. She still likes to think that she gets to both ask the questions and deliver the answers. That only she knows what the public really wants to hear.

title: Nadine Dorries is back – with her incisive thinking and deranged conspiracy theories
summary: Nadine Dorries is a woman of no regrets. Perfectly happy to live in the day. The past isn’t just another country, it’s a parallel universe. One where any inconsistencies and inconvenient truths are consigned to blissful oblivion. A danger to herself but a source of amusement to the rest of us. Politics has missed her incisive thinking and deranged conspiracy theories. There was just time for someone more searing of insight and searing insight of the brightest and the best to defect to Reform. But Nige was only interested in taking the very brightest and best of the best into the Tory party. It was only a matter of time before she blamed Michael Gove for the increase in immigration. And come to think of it, why hadn't Nadine said something about it when she was in Johnson's cabinet? That was because no one had told all these people into the country and it hadn't occurred to her to ask. She demanded to have another moment of silence for Boris.

title: ‘Such a vibrant feeling’: Reform UK devotees gather at party conference
summary: Party conference season has kicked off at a time when Nigel Farage’s organisation is enjoying as much as a 15-point lead over Labour. The numbers suggest it is gaining traction from new voters with a diversity of views, but the fervour of the Reform faithful was often as unfiltered as ever. “Has anyone noticed how Rachel from accounts looks startlingly like Richard III,” he said, using pejorative rightwing shorthand for Rachel Reeves, the chancellor. Elsewhere, sporting a “Make Britain Great Again” cap, William Payne rattled off what he described as the “burning priorities” to save Britain. � “There�s a unity of purpose here and it’m just really refreshing to come up and actually see that there is a plan to save this country. Reform UK is the only hope”

title: ‘A class act’: Tim Allan, the former Blair ‘smoother’ recalled to Downing Street
summary: Tim Allan is a smooth and impeccably well-connected PR man, according to those who have worked with him. But he has a job on his hands to turn around Downing Street’s faltering communications efforts. He will also have to deal with criticism over his previous clients. Some No 10 insiders resisted his appointment on the grounds that his former communications company, Portland, took on work to help improve the Kremlin's image. There is further potential for controversy over his role as a trustee for the gender critical Sex Matters charity, which he resigned to take on the No 10 job. Stonewall, the LGBTQ+ charity, wrote to Starmer this week objecting to Allan's role and questioning whether Sex Matters would get undue influence in government. Allan has a long history with the party, having moved in the same New Labour circles as the former cabinet ministers David Miliband and James Purnell.

title: Lammy refers himself to watchdog after fishing illegally with JD Vance
summary: David Lammy hosted JD Vance and his family at Chevening House in Kent. Anglers aged 13 and over must hold a rod licence to fish for freshwater species. Lammy failed to land a catch, but “all of my kids did,” Vance said. The Foreign Office said an “administrative oversight’ meant licences had not been obtained in advance. The agency confirmed the licences had since been bought. All fish caught during the visit were returned to the water. The fishing trip formed part of a wider UK tour by Vance, who was on holiday in the Cotswolds with his wife, Usha, and three children. Vance has held informal talks with senior Conservatives, including the shadow justice secretary, Robert Jenrick, and the shadow home secretary, Chris Philp.

title: Rachel Reeves is the only one grinning wildly at Keir and Kemi’s dreary display
summary: After last week's mini-meltdown during PMQs, the chancellor is now condemned to spend the next year grinning manically every time she’s out and about in public. To make it worse, you now get endless colleagues patting you on the shoulder and looking you deep in the eyes as they ask if you’re OK. When you just want to be left alone. But well done Kemi for doing the right thing. Unfortunately for her that was about the only thing she did get right. Not that Starmer himself was on sparkling form. It was more that Kemi felt a bit distracted herself. As though her heart wasn’t fully in it either. Semi-detached Kemi. This PMZs was just another chore to be ticked off the list. One to forget for all concerned. At times, it feels as if I must have been asleep by the time these exchanges were back during the election – and everything was now shit.

title: Keir Starmer in diplomatic push to head off Middle East crisis before G7 summit in Canada
summary: Downing Street did not rule out the possibility of having to evacuate UK nationals from Israel if matters deteriorated. The prime minister discussed the continuing clashes between Israel and Iran with the Canadian prime minister, Mark Carney, in Ottawa. Starmer’s programme for meetings at the summit has yet to be set out, but it is likely he will hold bilateral talks with leaders such as President Donald Trump, President Emmanuel Macron of France and the German chancellor, Friedrich Merz. Earlier on Sunday, the Foreign Office warned Britons against travel to Israel or the occupied Palestinian territories. The updated guidance warned that insurance policies may be invalidated, describing the crisis as a “fast-moving situation” posing “significant risks” It marks the biggest escalation of UK travel advice since October 2023, when the government urged citizens to avoid all but essential travel.

title: Three neo-Nazis jailed for plotting terror attacks on UK mosques and synagogues
summary: Christopher Ringrose, Marco Pitzettu and Brogan Stewart were jailed. They had amassed an arsenal of more than 200 weapons, a jury heard. The trio idolised Hitler and used racist slurs, the court heard. They were arrested when security services believed an attack was imminent. A jury rejected defence claims that the men were fantasists with no intention of carrying out their threats. A high court judge, Ms Justice Cutts, jailed Stewart for 11 years. Ringrose was jailed for 10 years and Pitzetu for eight years. The three men were found guilty of preparing acts of terrorism and of charges of collecting information likely to be useful to a person preparing or committing an act of terrorism. The trial heard that the arsenal included machetes, hunting knives, swords, axes, crossbows, body armour and a baseball bat.

title: Badenoch urged to ‘come clean’ after doubt cast on Stanford University claim
summary: Labour and the Lib Dems call for Kemi Badenoch to come clean about her claims. Former admissions staff said she had described an impossible scenario. The Conservative leader has defended her claim to have received an offer as a teenager in Nigeria to study medicine, sometimes described by her as pre-med, even though the university does not offer that course for undergraduates. The Labour MP Peter Prinsley has written to the Conservatives leader saying she should lay out the specifics of how the alleged offer came about. The Lib Dem education spokesperson, Munira Wilson, said Badench risked undermining trust. She doubled down on Monday, telling reporters she had indeed received offers based on her exam results. “But this is 30 years ago, I don’t have the papers, and what the Guardian is doing is reporting on hearsay rather than talking about what the government is doing,” she said.

title: Doubts cast on Kemi Badenoch’s claim of US medical school offer
summary: Kemi Badenoch has said she was offered place at prestigious US medical school. But admissions staff say they can't remember offering her a place at 16. Academic and admissions experts have cast doubt on this, saying it is impossible. Conservative party source said it was a common colloquialism to refer to taking a degree as “pre-med” Baden Coch was using this terminology having spent time in the US. Medicine is only offered to graduates at Stanford and there is no pre-med degree. She moved to the UK from Nigeria aged 16 and became an MP for Saffron Walden. She first mentioned her admission to Stanford in 2017, when she had just been elected as the Conservative MP for Saffron Walden. The same claim is made in a profile in the Daily Mail by Lord Ashcroft last year. On its website, the university says: “Stanford does not have a pre- med degree, for any of the health professions, you may major in any discipline.”

title: Journey times up, deaths down: Welsh 20mph speed limit still divisive two years on
summary: The change from 30mph was brought in by the Welsh Labour government in September 2023, at a cost of £34m. The reduced speed limit applied to any built-up area, defined as roads where lamp-posts were no more than about 180 metres apart. Last week a small study by GoSafe, which monitors road cameras, found the policy had added an average of two minutes to journey times of differing lengths. The Welsh Conservatives have consistently called for the law to be scrapped over what the party says is the confusion and frustration it causes for drivers. More than 130,000 drivers – or 34% of people with licences in Wales – have been caught breaking the lower limit since it was introduced, while the most recent YouGov polling, from a year ago, found seven in 10 people opposed the 20mph default.

title: ‘A palette unlike anything in the west’: Ben Okri, Yinka Shonibare and more on how Nigerian art revived Britain’s cultural landscape
summary: Nigerian artists in all their stripes created works that evoked their traditions but in a contemporary context. Artists such as Yusuf Grillo in the north, Bruce Onobrakpeya from the midwest, Ben Enwonwu from the east and Twins Seven Seven from the west were remaking the dream of art in a rigorously Nigerian context. The effect of the works created by the Zaria Art Society, the generation that congregated in Lagos and exhibited all over the world, was profound. Their work helped the nation to reconnect with its ancient ways, but adapted to modern times. It was a new art, brooding and celebratory. Often it was an art that hinted at the many dimensions of Nigerian mythology; often it drew upon daily realities. The other area in which this Nigerian modernism revealed itself is in the Nigerian novel. Works such as Chinua Achebe’s seminal Things Fall Apart, Wole Soyinka's The Interpreters are all works that depict a nation fermenting with energy and cultural tensions.

title: Louis CK defends decision to perform at Riyadh comedy festival as ‘a good opportunity’
summary: Dave Chappelle, Bill Burr, Kevin Hart, Pete Davidson, Whitney Cummings, Aziz Ansari, Hannibal Burress, Jim Jefferies, Jo Koy, Tom Segura and Jeff Ross are among the lineup at Riyadh comedy festival. Several comedians have questioned the ethics of performing comedy at a festival directly paid for by the Saudi Arabian government. The festival’s producers include Sela, a live events company owned by Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund; and the kingdom's General Entertainment Authority, which is chaired by Turki al-Sheikh. Human Rights Watch argued the festival was an effort by the government to whitewash its actions “amid significant increase in repression including a crackdown on free speech’” Comedians including Marc Maron, Atsuko Okatsuka and David Cross have been scathing of performers who have complained about cancel culture and censorship.

title: A drag queen stands at a site of violence: Lee-Ann Olwage’s best photograph
summary: Lee-Ann Olwage has been photographing South African drag queens for a year and a half. She wanted to use harsh lighting to emphasise the contrast between the strong jawlines and the feminine personae. She was concerned for the drag queens’ safety, not only while going to these sites of violence and making the images but also after, as some of them lived in the townships where the portraits would be made. But one thing Belinda said stuck with her. She said: “If we don’t go, if we don't reclaim these spaces and make these pictures, then it’s like wedon't exist” The entire series was shot in four hours. We met at a petrol station on the day, so theDrag queens could get ready – everyone had specific ideas about what they wanted to wear.

title: Get ready to rumble: how wrestling broke out of the ring and on to the stage
summary: Pro wrestling is dipping a greased-up toe into the theatrical limelight. The sport has a rich working-class history, growing from the grassroots to raising some of the greatest international contenders such as Will Ospreay and Zack Sabre Jr. A smattering of productions across the UK welcoming new audiences through alternative performance lenses, from comedy to queer cabaret to a living sculpture that uses bondage to suspend disbelief. Clash of the Comics, the brutal showdown that saw Rosie Jones defeat Greg Davies at the O2, as part of the 2023 Just for Laughs festival, is about to take over the Hammersmith Apollo, west London. The lineup includes pro wrestlers Simon Miller, Cara Noir and La Cyclonica, with comedians Aisling Bea, Flo & Joan and James Acaster, who has issued an open challenge to any comedian or wrestler willing to take him on. The comedians are sent to wrestling school to make their transformations possible.

title: From One Battle After Another to the Turner prize: your complete entertainment guide to the week ahead
summary: The Strangers: Chapter 2 is the fourth film in the Strangers home-invasion horror franchise. The BBC National Orchestra of Wales marks the 50th anniversary of the death of Shostakovich with a performance of his most massive symphony, No 7 in C, the Leningrad. The ever-innovative Polish jazz scene’s 2025 festival London festival showcases both established and rising stars. The Magnetic Fields’ sixth album 69 Love Songs has rightly taken up classic status. British R&B girl band Flo tour in support of last year's buttery soft debut LP Access All Areas. Marie Antoinette Style Vamp;A Style is revived as a style icon in modern pop culture. Yuki Kihara gives the theory of evolution a queer twist by mocking the white male icons are deconstructed in a show that combines Paradise Camp, an installation inspired by Darwin, with a video entitled Dragguin Tahiti. The Turner prize 2025 Cartwright Hall Art Gallery, Bradford, 27 September to 22 February.

title: Bill Burr calls critics of Riyadh comedy festival ‘sanctimonious’ and ‘phoney’
summary: Bill Burr has defended his appearance at the Riyadh comedy festival. The comedian has been under fire, alongside Kevin Hart, Louis CK, Aziz Ansari and Dave Chappelle, for being on the lineup. The Human Rights Watch called out the event as a distraction, aiming to focus on something light rather than the “soaring number of executions” taking place. Burr spoke to Conan O’Brien as part of a live podcast, and said he felt “wonderful” about his appearance. He claimed he was one of the comedians who had “the most amount of shit” for appearing. He also said that the US was “moving towards” Saudi Arabia with Ice “fucking grabbing moms and dads and sticking them in a van for making illegally made fucking tacos”

title: ‘Dictator-for-life vibes’: our architecture critic on Trump’s bulletproof ballroom bling
summary: Donald Trump has decreed the East Wing not fit for purpose. He plans to replace it with a faux classical bulletproof ballroom, capable of seating up to 650 partygoers. Costing $250m (£187.5m), it is one of the most grandiose White House projects to be implemented in more than a century. The American Institute of Architects is wearily wary, stating: “AIA is extremely concerned about any revisions that remove control from local communities’ Trump’s style edicts and building bombast exude a dictator-for-life megalomania vibe, as he barrels through his second term. However, he is said to dislike the White House, finding it on the poky side, preferring to decamp to his Floridian resort Mar-a-Lago at every opportunity.

title: Stephen Colbert on Trump’s White House East Wing demolition: ‘So deeply unsettling’
summary: Late-night hosts reacted to Donald Trump's partial demolition of the East Wing of the White House for his proposed $250m gilded ballroom. Trump claimed that the project would “not interfere with the current building” because it would be “near it but not touching it” and “paying total respect to the existing building, which I’m the biggest fan of, it’s my favorite” The treasury department has even instructed its employees not to share any photos of White House “construction” “Hey guys, remember, no photos at my wedding … and it's not because I'm marrying a body pillow of Mariah Carey,’” said Stephen Colbert on the Late Show. “Apparently ‘not touching’ the White. House turned into ‘demolishing’ The White House,” joked Michael Kosta on the Daily Show.

title: Seth Meyers on Trump’s White House ballroom: ‘This couldn’t be any more of a bait and switch’
summary: Late-night hosts mocked Donald Trump's demolition of the East Wing of the White House and the corporate sponsors of his $300m gilded ballroom. The National Trust for Historic Preservation sent a letter to Trump saying that the addition would overwhelm the structure and asked him to pause construction until the plans could be reviewed. Trump has funded the “ball-doggle’ with money from “groveling corporations” including Amazon, Apple, Comcast, Google, Microsoft, T-Mobile, Meta Platforms and Hard Rock International. The estimated cost has already risen from an initial $250m to over $300M, for a 90,000 sq-ft (8,400 sq-meter) construction, larger than the existing White House itself. “That’s about the same size as a professional soccer field,” said Stephen Colbert.

title: Bob Vylan ‘not regretful’ about IDF chant at Glastonbury: ‘I’d do it again tomorrow’
summary: Bobby Vylan says he is 'not regretful' of his 'death, death to the IDF' chant at Glastonbury. He said the backlash the band had faced was 'minimal compared to what people in Palestine are going through' Vylan also hit back at Damon Albarn from Blur, who called the chant “one of the most spectacular misfires I’ve seen in my life” and described Vylan as “goose-stepping in tennis gear” The musician said he was taken aback by the uproar sparked by the chant, and claimed members of BBC staff told him on the day that the set was ‘fantastic’ The BBC’s executive complaints unit (ECU) has since found the broadcast of the performance breached editorial standards in relation to harm and offence.

title: Basslines over goalposts, cricket club bhangra nights: the gatherings where British diaspora music really grows
summary: The sounds that have shaped me as a Black British person aren’t designed by algorithms or commissioned by labels. They come from battered speakers balanced on trestle tables, bhangra basslines rattling the walls of community centres in Southall. Aunties send gospel remixes with laughing emojis, cousins drop raw Warsaw drill tracks such as Lola by Żabson and friends digitise Somali oud tapes that are not on any streaming platform. Within hours, a playlist builds itself out of scraps, memes and masterpieces. It is chaotic, but it is magic. These diasporic exchanges and cultural networks are pushed to the margins of Britain’s mainstream music narrative. Despite their energy and influence, they rarely receive the same visibility or institutional support as other scenes that emerge with commercial polish.

title: Chappell Roan review – pop’s patient princess triumphantly takes the throne in New York
summary: Chappell Roan performed at Forest Hills stadium in New York on Sunday. It was her first live show in the US in a year. Her eight “pop-up” shows this fall span the geographical linchpins of her music. A 93-minute set containing almost every song she’s recorded had the feeling of a greatest hits show. Roan is easily one of the strongest vocalists of her pop generation, though she was occasionally overwhelmed by the joyous din – whether for illness or celebration, she often let the audience take over. She was allegedly not “feeling 100” on Sunday night – “I have a migraine, so I can’t bang my head super hard,” she said before nominally teaching the YMCA-style Hot To Go! dance to 13,000 devotees.

title: From Bugonia to All’s Fair: your complete entertainment guide to the week ahead
summary: Yorgos Lanthimos returns with something that you might not expect from him: a remake. Palestine 36 explores events leading up to the Arab revolt of 1936, when Palestinians tried to gain independence from British colonial rule. Brothers Jack and George Barnett take their fifth album, Crooked Wing, on tour. Ravyn Lenae's Love Me Not encapsulates her unique take on soft-focus pop-R&B, all cascading melodies and lyrics that investigate love’s turf wars, wrapped in a supple soprano. Tom Morris has pulled together a cracking cast for his new take on Othello – with David Harewood as the jealous soldier and Toby Jones as the scheming scheming soldier. The Makropulos Case has taken 99 years for one of the 20th century's greatest operas to reach Covent Garden. A Story of South Asian Art by Mrinalini Mukherjee, who died in 2015, had a huge impact on post-second world war modern art in India.

title: ‘She’s leaning into the idea that her image is a gilded fantasy’: how Taylor Swift embraced the showgirl
summary: Swift made The Life of a Showgirl with Swedish super-producers Max Martin and Shellback while touring Europe last year. Album imagery by fashion photographers Mert Alas and Marcus Piggott shows Swift bejewelled with diamantes, fishnet tights, fur and feathered headdresses. Swift isn’t the first pop star to draw from the 19th-century showgirl tradition. Kylie Minogue chose to celebrate her ‘long-term relationship’ with fans with her art deco-inspired Showgirl tour of 2005. Lady Gaga acknowledged her debt to cabaret at last year’s Paris Olympics. Sabrina Carpenter�s skits draw from vaudeville while Addison Rae often wears sequins, tulle and lingerie-inspired looks. For pop stars such as these, the showgirl offers both stage-ready looks and historical context. But she has never been mere spectacle, argues Alison J Carr, the Sheffield-based author of Viewing Pleasure and Being a Showgirls.

title: ‘The label made 500 copies – we sold it in corner shops’: the story behind lost dance music classic Punjabi Disco
summary: Punjabi Disco is the holy grail of British Asian music, says DJ Raghav Mani. The nine-track album combines producer Kuljit Bhamra’s searing synthesiser melodies and hammering drum machine rhythms with the Punjabi-language folk singing of his classically trained mother. Limited to only 500 copies, the record disappeared from circulation almost as quickly as it was released in 1982. In the decades since, rare copies have materialised online for thousands of dollars but it has otherwise vanished into obscurity. That was until Mani and his business partner Filip Nikolic decided to see if Kuljit was willing to release a reissue on their archival label Naya Beat. “It was a three-year process, from first hearing the record to Kuljit finding the original master tapes in his house and digitising them before they completely degraded,” Mani says, “During that time, we discovered that not only is it an incredible-sounding album that more people need to hear but it also has a crazy story behind its making”

title: Garden Reflexxx: the 10 funniest things we have ever seen (on the internet)
summary: Fyi Radio’s Movies Movies Movies has compiled a list of five of their favourite films. The list is in preparation for our upcoming film festival at the Sydney Opera House. We’ve focused on what worked for us in this particular moment of time. Here, we look at the work of Alice Barker, Macy Rodman, Lushious Massacr, Gal Palz and Patti Harrison. We also take a look at some of our favourite short films of all time. We hope you’ll enjoy the list as much as we did. For the rest of the list, please visit our Facebook page and follow us on Twitter @FyiRadioMovies and @fyiradioMovies. Back to the page you came from. Click here to read the full list and watch the video below. The film festival will take place at the Opera House, Sydney, from September 26-28. For more information, visit fyiradio.co.uk.

title: Jon Stewart on Trump’s Gatsby party: ‘The theme was apparently gross income inequality’
summary: Late-night hosts reacted to Donald Trump's Great Gatsby-themed Halloween party held just hours before millions of Americans lost their food stamp benefits. Jon Stewart mocked House speaker Mike Johnson’s insistence that Trump is “desperate for Snap benefits to flow to the American people” Stephen Colbert: “No one should understand the importance of daily meals more than Donald Trump.” Jimmy Kimmel: ‘What do you do when you have a terrible approval rating? You throw the most ill-timed, tone-deaf Halloween party imaginable,’ he said. “It felt like the big bash of all time,” he said of the last time he felt like throwing a big bash. ‘You know, throwing a party at your private golf club where the theme is white people are set to lose their food assistance might be the Trumpiest move of all.’ “Of course, like all good news during the Trump administration, he managed to make it bad,“ said Colbert.

title: Danny Thompson obituary
summary: Danny Thompson, who has died aged 86, was a musician’s musician. His fluid playing enriched the albums Five Leaves Left (1969) by Drake and Solid Air ( 1973) by Martyn. He went on to form a long working relationship with Martyn, and, later, the singer-songwriter Richard Thompson (no relation) Thompson was born in Teignmouth, Devon. He never knew his father, a miner who enrolled in the Royal Navy at the start of the second world war and was killed in action. He and Richard Thompson recorded 14 albums together. Last year, he performed at Richard”s 75th birthday concert at the Royal Albert Hall. He was arrested for failing to turn up for a national tour – watching the Beatles head off – while playing electric bass for the only time in his life. He also played on the recording for the theme music of the TV series Thunderbirds. In 1987 Thompson released his debut solo album, Whatever, leading a jazz trio playing the muscular fusion he loved.

title: Jack DeJohnette obituary
summary: Jack DeJohnette was a percussionist, pianist, composer and bandleader. His CV glitters with the names of the biggest jazz stars of the second half of the 20th century. An athletic, muscular drummer who played the kit at arm’s length as if boxing with it, he could maintain thundering funk/rock grooves for long stretches, as he often did for Miles Davis on dark, turbulent sessions, such as Live Evil and Live at the Fillmore East in 1970. In his later years he toured and recorded occasionally as a solo pianist. Jack was the only child of Eva (nee Wood) and Jack De Johnette Sr. He began taking piano lessons at around the age of four, and his musical aptitudes were nurtured by his uncle, Roy Wood, a radio DJ, who would play him records by Duke Ellington and Billie Holiday. As a teenager, he began singing doo-wop, and playing piano modelled on Domino.

title: Donna Jean Godchaux supplied steel and soul to the Grateful Dead in their prime
summary: Donna Jean Godchaux was not a fan of the Grateful Dead when she arrived in California in 1970. She offered to attend a Dead show sober, certain she would hate it. It proved a fateful decision. By the end of the Dead’s set at the Winterland Ballroom, Thatcher – ostensibly retired from music – had announced: “If I sing again, it will be with this band” Steeped in a different musical tradition to the rest of the band, her voice swiftly became part of their sound, as evidenced by her contributions to Bob Weir's solo debut Ace. On one notable occasion during the Europe ’72 tour, she took to the stage having taken 15 hits of LSD, unaware that the band's supply – which had been weakening in strength as the tour progressed – had been replenished with fresh, undiluted provisions. In her account, she spent most of the show lying prone under her husband's piano, but somehow still made it to the microphone in time to sing.

title: Jon Stewart on Trump’s taunts of an illegal third term: ‘We know he’s thought about it’
summary: Jon Stewart assessed the threat of Trump attempting to run for a third term as president, which is illegal under the 22nd amendment to the constitution. “Indications are very clear he’s gonna do it,” he continued, “because you don’t move into a house, knock down a wing and build a 90,000-sq-ft ballroom for the next guy’” Jimmy Kimmel returned from a weeklong family trip to Ireland with renewed perspective on his home country. ‘They’re worried about us in the same way you worry about a nephew who you maybe haven't seen for a few years and he shows up at Thanksgiving missing all of his front teeth? That kind of worry,’ he said. On Late Night, Seth Meyers touched on the Trump 2028 hats seen on his desk during meetings with congressional Democrats. � “So Trump put some hats on the desk during a meeting with Democrats, he says that wearing a Trump hat is like wearing a Super Bowl champion New York Jets hat.’ “All we know, only we know is that the solution was to completely smash the whole place down in private in private. I wish the master builder would do like the rest of us do us”

title: Jimmy Kimmel on the Republicans: ‘So much greed and hypocrisy and duplicity’
summary: Late-night hosts spoke about Donald Trump’s attempts to transform the White House and how he was “cashing in bigly” on being president. Kimmel said there is “so much greed and hypocrisy and duplicity” in the party with the House speaker, Mike Johnson, still blaming Democrats for the government shutdown. Colbert joked that if Johnson had a time machine, “would he use it to go back and kiss baby Hitler?” This Saturday will see nationwide protests against Trump”s authoritarian rule, and even though they are aiming to be peaceful, Kimmel said that on Fox they will be painted as “violent, vicious Antifa riots” The right has already been calling them “Hate America” rallies.

title: Laurence Fox’s libel claim over racism accusations to go to retrial
summary: Former actor was sued by Simon Blake and Crystal over a row on Twitter. Fox called Blake and the former RuPaul’s Drag Race contestant ‘paedophiles’ Judge ruled in favour of Blake and Seymour and said Fox should pay them £90,000 each in damages. Fox challenged this decision at the court of appeal in London. Lord Justice Dingemans, Lady Justice Elisabeth Laing and Lord Justice Warby ruled in Fox's favour on his counter-claims and the level of damages. Warby said the tweets describing Fox as a racist caused serious harm to his reputation and his libel claim should be reconsidered at a retrial. He also reduced the amount of damages Fox was ordered to pay toBlake and Seymour to £45,000, describing the previous sums as “manifestly excessive”

title: From glorified sheds to sleek sci-fi palaces: how architecture put the zing into football grounds
summary: Home Ground is a new exhibition on the architecture and social culture of football stadiums. Liverpool is a serendipitous setting for a dive into the history and destiny of football grounds. The exhibition’s chronological sweep opens with a 1906 plan of Anfield by Scottish architect Archibald Leitch. England may have invented and formalised the game, but in the matter of stadium design, it was its European neighbours who really ran with the ball. In Florence, Fiorentina employed the renowned modernist Pier Luigi Nervi to devise a graceful exercise in reinforced concrete. In Rotterdam, Feyenoord”s stadium of 1937 embodied the functionalist ideals of the Dutch Nieuwe Bouwen (New Building) movement, with a lightweight, skeletal steel frame used to suspend the upper tier above the lower, offering an unimpeded view of the pitch. In the part dedicated to Italia 90, graphic designer Alberto Burri's definitive World Cup poster features a football pitch in the Colosseum, the ur-stadium and theoretical point of origin.

title: Romeo a Juliet review – star-crossed lovers divided by language
summary: In Theatr Cymru’s bilingual tragedy, alternating between Shakespeare's English and JT Jones's Welsh translation, the uttering of any word acquires a particular salience. While the ambitious concept opens the possibility of exploring linguistic identity, its impact feels nebulous when the deployment of different languages is not underpinned by dramatic logic. The experience can feel discordant and the scenes performed mostly in one language or the other (and one particularly elegiac sequence with no words at all) are more compelling. As a production, it clearly speaks from the calon. But as well as that heart, you yearn for more logic.

title: Trump and Project 2025 are attacking the Department of Education. How might they reshape US schools?
summary: Donald Trump wants to shut down the US Department of Education. The idea of dismantling the education department has become increasingly mainstream. Trump made similar promises on the 2016 campaign trail to either cut or hobble the department. Eliminating it would require Congress to act, which could be an impossible feat. But several of Trump and his allies’ policy goals on education could be accomplished through presidential actions. The Heritage Foundation’s rightwing manifesto for a potential incoming Trump administration lays out how dismantling the federal education department would work. Project 2025 calls for privatizing education and driving out any programs related to LGBTQ+ youth or diversity. It says states should be given money with no strings attached to spend it on “any education purpose under state law” The project proposes phasing out one major program, Title I, over a 10-year period. Instead, the project says states “should assume control over how to provide a quality education to children from low-income families”

title: UK students urged to mind terror laws before 7 October pro-Palestine protests
summary: Up to 10 events are thought to have been planned on or near campuses on Tuesday. It will be the second anniversary of the Hamas attacks on Israel, which left 1,200 people dead, many more injured or kidnapped and sparked the Israeli offensive in Gaza. Universities UK wrote to members last week after the attack on Heaton Park synagogue in Manchester, warning that the anniversary was a “potential flashpoint” and urging members to “review security arrangements”. Details of the London march are posted on Instagram under the banner headline: “Inter-university march. Two years of genocide and our institutions remain complicit” It calls for a walkout of classes at 2pm, with the route taking in King’s College London (KCL), the London School of Economics, University College London and finishing at SOAS.

title: Jane Plastow obituary
summary: Jane Plastow was an academic and theatre-maker based at the University of Leeds. She made invaluable contributions to the fields of community-based theatre, African studies and global development. Jane led the Centre for African Studies at Leeds from 2004 to 2014. In 2006 she was made professor of African theatre, with the Nobel laureate Wole Soyinka attending her inaugural lecture. Most recently, Jane had a longstanding collaboration with We Are Walukuba, a community group in Jinja, Uganda. She had an unrelenting and unstoppable energy and an enormous sense of fun. She is survived by Will, her brother, John, and sisters Beverley and Caroline. Her uncompleted final book, provisionally titled Keir Starmer’s Political Prisoners, highlighted the increasingly severe state crackdown on dissent in the UK.

title: President-elect of Oxford Union to face disciplinary proceedings for Charlie Kirk remarks
summary: George Abaraonye, president-elect of the Oxford Union, will face disciplinary proceedings. He made 'inappropriate remarks' celebrating the fatal shooting of Charlie Kirk. Union says it is 'deeply disturbed' by the racial abuse and threats he has received. He said he had 'reacted impulsively' to the news of Kirk's shooting and the comments were 'quickly deleted' Abaraoneye and Kirk met during a debate on toxic masculinity held by the Union in May. The master of University College, Oxford, said no disciplinary action would be taken against AbaraONYe by the college he attends. He added that free speech ‘cannot and will not come at the expense of violence, intimidation, or hate’ in a statement posted on social media.

title: African history students awarded compensation after master’s axed
summary: University of Chichester terminated African history course in 2023. Course leader Prof Hakim Adi was made redundant without warning. Thirteen students took legal action against the university. Office of the Independent Adjudicator for Higher Education ruled in favour of students. The university has been ordered to pay compensation to the affected students. It came amid a crippling financial crisis affecting higher education across the UK. The decision is a significant step in the fight for racial justice and educational fairness, says the Black Equity Organisation. The MRes in the history of Africa and the African diaspora regrettably closed to new applicants in. 2023, but we are making every effort to work with continuing students so that they can complete their studies. We refute any suggestion of discrimination and note that the OIA claim was only partially upheld on the basis of procedural issues.

title: Sacking of Christian school worker over posts about LGBTQ+ lessons unlawful, court rules
summary: Kristie Higgs was dismissed from her role as a pastoral administrator and work experience manager at Farmor's, a secondary school in Fairford, Gloucestershire. She was dismissed after reposting and commenting on messages on her personal Facebook account that criticised plans to teach the No Outsiders equalities programme at her son's primary school. The posts referred to “brainwashing” children and criticised the teaching of “gender fluidity” and the view that same-sex marriage was equivalent to marriage between a man and a woman. An employment tribunal found in 2020 that while Higgs’s religion was a protected characteristic, her dismissal was still lawful. This decision was subsequently overturned by an employment appeal tribunal (EAT) in 2023. The EAT then ruled the case should be sent back to an employment tribunal for a fresh decision, which Higgs's lawyers challenged in the court of appeal.

title: UK university cuts threaten to ‘wipe out’ black scholarship, academics say
summary: Leading academics and students are raising the alarm that these cuts are falling on lecturers and courses that played a leading role in addressing racial disparities in higher education. University of Chichester made Prof Hakim Adi redundant and cut his MRes on the history of Africa and the African diaspora. Prof Robert Beckford, the well-known theologian who researched climate and social justice, has been made redundant at the University of Winchester. Birmingham City University (BCU) shuttered its black studies undergraduate course. Goldsmiths, University of London reversed plans to cut its Black British literature MA, stating it would commit to running the course for another two years. But it recently made the founder and convener of the course, Prof Deirdre Obsorne, redundant.

title: ‘Huge step in the right direction’: arts leaders hail move to boost creative subjects in England’s schools
summary: Department for Education wants to boost creative subjects at GCSE. Changes include scrapping the English baccalaureate (Ebacc) Andrew Lloyd Webber says there is still no flesh on the bones in the government’s latest announcement. The number of UK students taking arts subjects has plummeted in recent years. Since 2010, enrolment in arts GCSEs has fallen by 40% and the number of arts teachers has declined by 23%. Research last year found that a decade ago about half of all A-level students took at least one humanities subject. By 2021-22 that had fallen to 38%, with the proportion taking arts. subjects such as music, design and media studies dropping to 24%. The latest GCSE data showed the situation had got even worse. since 2010, enrollment in artsGCSEs. has fall by 40%. The proportion of students taking. arts subjects at A-Levels has plummeted, leading to a creativity crisis in state schools.

title: One in 12 secondary pupils put in isolation rooms at least once a week, study finds
summary: Pupils on free school meals more than one-and-a-half times more likely to be placed in isolation than their wealthier peers. Children who identified as LGBTQ+ were nearly twice as likely to being in isolation. Black, Asian and mixed heritage children were also more likely than their white British peers, the research from the University of Manchester found. Isolation usually involves removing a pupil from a class for disruptive behaviour and asking them to work alone or in silence in a separate room. Parents complain that children can be put into isolation for minor breaches of school rules, which those with complex behaviours and special needs may find difficult to adhere to. Unlike suspensions or permanent exclusions, there are no national rules on how isolation should be used, or for how long, and there is no publicly available national data.

title: Partial to pre-drinks and a party? Your guide to getting the most out of student nightlife
summary: A good night out can foster the sense of connection and friendship that is key to a student’s wellbeing. The eye-watering cost of going out now means that the time-honoured student tradition of cramming into the communal kitchen for pre-drinks is alive and well. Demand for activities-based nights out, including pottery painting and crafting, is also skyrocketing – with their fixed cost one of the main draws, says Katie Kirwan, head of brand at booking platform Design My Night. But don’t believe everything they tell you about gen Z – they’re as partial to a party as their predecessors, just more discerning about where they choose to blow their student loan. So which universities make the grade for their social scenes?

title: Revealed: Harvard publisher cancels entire journal issue on Palestine shortly before publication
summary: Harvard Educational Review put out a call for submissions for a special issue on "education and Palestine" The publisher abruptly canceled the issue, citing "a number of complex issues," the Guardian has learned. The cancellation of an entire issue of an academic journal, which has not been previously reported, is a remarkable new development in a mounting list of examples of censorship of pro-Palestinian speech. “If the universities – or in this case a university press – are not willing to stand up for what is core to their mission, I don’t know what they’re doing. What’s the point?” said Thea Abu El-Haj, a Palestinian-American anthropologist of education at Barnard College, who was one of the solicited authors for the special issue. The issue was slated to be published this summer, and contracts with most authors were finalized and articles were edited. But the publisher demanded that the articles be submitted to a legal review late, a step the authors called a “dangerous form of institutional censorship”

title: Majority of girls and young women in UK alter behaviour to feel safe, study finds
summary: 56% of girls and young women aged between 11 and 21 said they feel unsafe travelling by themselves, up from 45% in 2022. 86% of respondents have avoided going out after dark to stay safe, with girls of colour less likely to step out. More than half of girls aged 11 to 18 said they had experienced male pupils making toxic comments while 32% reported seeing a teacher or member of staff subjected to sexist or misogynistic abuse. Girls with disabilities felt particularly unsafe travelling, with only 17% saying they felt secure on public transport, compared with 33% of non-disabled girls. Girlguiding called on local authorities and schools to publish plans to tackle misogyny in their communities and for politicians in charge of public transport to engage with girls on their fears and make services safer.

title: UK government urged to introduce GCSE in Ukrainian for child refugees
summary: Ukrainian children living here in the UK are the future of their country. They will play a vital role in its recovery, so we must match their level of ambition and make sure they receive all the support possible to thrive in their education. Department for Education has also set up a working group to help implement the move. One of the exam boards, AQA, said it was carefully considering reintroducing the qualification. But education sector insiders are sceptical about the practicalities of the move and say a GCSE is not going to help students who are currently here who have fled Ukraine. St Mary’s has proposed becoming a hub for both GCSE and A-level qualifications in Ukrainian. It said: “Establishing a Ukrainian GCSE centre will provide these children with opportunities to take UkrainianGCSE and a-level exams, supporting their educational and professional goals”

title: Liam Ó Bruadair obituary
summary: Liam Ó Bruadair, who has died aged 86, was my father’s best friend. In the late 1960s, Liam and his, wife Cristín McGuinness, together with eight other couples, decided they wished to raise their families in the Irish language. They built nine houses on the Shaws Road on the outskirts of West Belfast, and opened a primary school, Bunscoil Phobal Feirste, in 1971. At a time when a hostile unionist establishment still ruled at Stormont, it was the first Irish-medium school in Belfast in centuries. They had to fund it themselves until 1984, when the Department of Education (Northern Ireland) took it over. Today it has 400 pupils and a modern building. There are now nine such primary schools and a thriving secondary school.

title: ‘It enriches your mind in every way’: the fight to keep the UK learning German
summary: Amber Tallon started learning German at the age of 12 and now works as a Blue Badge Guide in London. Caroline Wyatt, a BBC presenter whose long career as a foreign correspondent started in Berlin in the early 90s thanks to her German language skills, says learning German “really enriched my life as a human being” The number of pupils having chosen to study German at A-Level in 2024 standing at just 2,261. Entries for German have more than halved over the last decade, there is an increasing dearth of German teachers and some higher education institutes are considering closing down their German departments. The Association for German Studies in Great Britain and Ireland will meet for its 92nd annual conference next month. The German ambassador to the UK, Miguel Berger, is behind the initiative “Making the Case for German”, together with the Goethe Institut, and the UK Department for Education.

title: Hilary Hester Ives obituary
summary: Hilary developed a pedagogy that focused on developing the language skills of children at different stages of learning English. Based on extensive research by teachers throughout the country, this was widely disseminated to teachers through in-service training. Hilary was born in Aldershot, Hampshire, to Len Shreeves, a soldier, and his wife, Joan, a shopkeeper. She qualified as a teacher in 1955 after studying at Whitelands College in Roehampton, south-west London, where she met John Hester. They married in 1956, and after a spell teaching in a Reading primary school, she and John moved to Ethiopia in 1958 with their baby son, Simon. She taught English in secondary schools in Addis Ababa, but she disliked the stultifying expatriate life and returned to the UK in 1964.

title: Maggie Ross obituary
summary: Maggie Ross, who has died suddenly aged 73, was an inspiring early years educator. She brought practical compassion and understanding in supporting the families of young children. As the manager of nurseries and early years centres in London, she had a particular flair for helping her staff to aspire to develop their careers. Maggie is survived by me, her two children and four grandsons. She spent some of her early life in Kerala, south India, where her father taught. She went to Accrington high school. Maggie and I first met in late 1971 at Soas University of London. She trained as an early years teacher, and then took a course in teaching bilingual children at the Inner London Education Authority’s centre for urban educational studies. After a short break when our children, Susanna and David, were born, she moved to teach in the nursery class at Highbury Quadrant primary school.

title: Jenga, dodgeball and no phones: a London school’s radical 12-hour day
summary: All Saints Catholic College in London is piloting a 12-hour school day. From 7am to 7pm on Monday to Thursday the youngest pupils, in years 7 and 8, could stay in school. For £10 a week, they would be served a cooked breakfast and ‘family’ dinner, and offered activities from drama to ceramics and sports. The only catch: their phones had to remain in their bags, switched off, for the entire 12 hours. When the normal school day ends at 3.15pm, the extended provision begins again. Headteacher Andrew O’Neill says phones have been at the heart of so many recent problems in the 900-pupil school, including sexting, bullying and online extortion. “There is a sort of media culture where we try to turn early teens, pre-teens, into adults, way before they’re ready, unless you just allow them to remain being children,” he says. Despite its location among the multimillion-pound white stucco mansions, All Saints serves a community of high deprivation.

title: Soaring costs trigger calls to address transport for Send pupils in England
summary: Home-to-school transport costs in England have risen to £2.3bn a year. Increasing numbers of children with special educational needs and disabilities travel farther afield to schools that can meet their requirements. More than half a million children and young people up to the age of 25 now get council-funded transport from their home to school or college. Of the 470,000 children under 16 who benefit, about 40% (180,000) have special educationalneeds and disabilities (Send) Councils spend approximately five times more on transport for Send pupils than others (£8,116 v £1,526), as they often have to travel further in single-occupancy taxis, contributing to a 70% real-terms increase in spending overall in the past eight years. Government announced last week it was delaying the publication of its long-awaited white paper detailing plans to overhaul Send provision.

title: David Peck obituary
summary: David Peck was principal careers officer (PCO) for Shropshire. Served as president of the Institute of Careers Officers and as chair of the Association of PCOs. A passionate advocate for the profession, he was never afraid to stand up to politicians to further the case for career guidance for people of all ages. His strong sense of ethics often put him one step ahead of the trends, and he advocated for young people in areas of rural deprivation, and women returning to work. David was known for his wry sense of humour and being able to conceal his irritation when faced with a lack of understanding of career guidance. He is survived by his children, Sarah and me, five grandchildren, three great-grandchildren and his siblings Daphne and Duncan.

title: Adult education should be for life, not just a job
summary: The proportion of adults in further education is now at its lowest since the 1940s. The decline began in the 1990s, when meeting the needs of employers – rather than on all-round provision for life – became the obsession. After the Treasury’s 2006 Leitch review called for further “strengthening employer voice” in the system, participation went into freefall. The white paper says nothing about education for democracy; community, equality and social inclusion receive hardly a mention. Only universities (not further education) are encouraged to develop “civic plans” But this mixed bag is no radical approach. It is the failed recipe of decades past, with the odd new herb. It has no “broad and generous, humane and liberal spirit”

title: ‘You just have to laugh’: five teachers on dealing with ‘six-seven’ in the classroom
summary: Pupils have been shouting out the words ‘six-seven’ during lessons. It is the latest meme-based craze to sweep through classrooms. While some teachers have chosen to stoically ignore the trend, others have embraced it. Five teachers explain how they’re coping with the craze in their classrooms. ‘If you give oxygen to it, then it becomes an inferno’ ‘They want to feel a part of a group’‘It’s like a call-and-response or a football chant – an agreed language they share’ The craze will die out soon, especially once their younger siblings start saying it,’ says Jane, 50, a primary school teacher in north-west England. “You just have to laugh with them,” says James, 24, a secondary school teacher, north London. � “Skibidi” was a similar craze when I was at school and I’m 24 years old, but I had no idea what it was at the time.”

title: There must be an Engels (playing with my chart)
summary: The research on which you report reads like a deliberate attempt to diminish the nature and extent of class differences that Engels observed and wrote about. In Moss Side and Hulme in the 1970s and 80s there were some professional people living there whom I knew, but the overwhelming majority of inhabitants were working class, and many of them impoverished and discriminated against. To suggest class was not that important is surely to throw the baby out with the bathwater. Prof Ralph Darlington Manchester. Emily Chung has used modern historical research methods to suggest that Friedrich Engels’ 1844 study of the Manchester working class was as much polemic as social investigation.

title: Oxford Union condemns president-elect’s reported comments on Charlie Kirk shooting
summary: George Abaraonye, president-elect of the debating society, made comments. One message was reported to have said “Charlie Kirk got shot, let’s fucking go” Kirk, 31, was killed at a Utah Valley University show on Wednesday in what authorities have called a political assassination. In response, the Oxford Union condemned the student's comments and said it ‘firmly opposes all forms of political violence and strongly stands by our commitment to free speech and considerate debate’ Abaraoneye said he had “reacted impulsively’ to the news of Kirk's shooting, and that the comments were “quickly deleted” after news emerged of his death. He added: “Those words did not reflect my values”

title: Former West Coast player Mitch Brown becomes first AFL player to come out as bisexual
summary: Mitch Brown has become the first male AFL player, past or present, to come out as gay or bisexual. The 36-year-old played 94 matches for West Coast in a career that ended in 2016. He identifies as a bisexual man and is in a long-term relationship with a woman. Brown said it would have been difficult had he spoken publicly during his playing career, but was motivated to help change the culture within the sport. “What matters to me most is a sense of change, [creating] a movement where [players] can be anyone and be safe in any environment,” he said. The news was widely welcomed on social media. The AFL Players’ Association described the post as “powerful’ and the GWS Giants’ account responded with a heart emoji.

title: The NHL preached inclusion. So why has it got into bed with Donald Trump?
summary: NHL commissioner Gary Bettman is a member of Donald Trump’s sports council. Bettman has given mixed messages around social issues in the past. The NHL tried to host a career fair aimed at recruiting a more diverse workforce in 2023. A few weeks later, the NHL again had the opportunity to stand for its diversity values when a handful of players refused to wear their team's Pride-themed warmup jerseys. But the NHL retreated meekly, encouraging “voices and perspectives on social and cultural issues.’’ The NHL pretends that these views are all morally equivalent when they’re not,’ writes John Sutter. “To see [Bettman, Gretzky, and Tkachuk] get behind an administration that is targeting marginalized communities, especially trans people, is a huge step backwards in making hockey a more inclusive sport,” he says.

title: Inclusive Brighton is perfect venue for World Cup’s sell-out party weekend
summary: World Rugby is releasing a short film called Where We Belong, directed by the duo Pip + Lib, emphasising rugby’s inclusivity. The executive team is all-female. So are the artists who created the opening TV credits, the DJs, and the groundstaff at the final. “Society has a long way to go before rugby is seen as a role model for the LGBT community,” says Pip. The irony is that the macho culture of the game has made so many people feel so alienated from the sport for so long. The women's game has always been ahead of the men in a way that is very different to the way it was in the 1980s and 1990s. It is about a sport where anyone wants to play. I don’t think we’ve ever heard any girls talk passionately about a rugby team that I’m about to play in.” – World Rugby director Sarah Massey.

title: UFC landed a $7.7bn deal with Paramount. But is Dana White’s Trump bond a liability?
summary: MMA is far more diverse and cerebral than the casual onlooker realizes. Dana White has long sought to expand the sport’s appeal to as many demographics as possible. While Maga champions an “America First” ideology, the UFC is a paragon of globalism. Of the 11 reigning UFC champions, only one is American – Kayla Harrison, thriving in an organization White once insisted would exclude women. The only belt firmly held by US fighters is the unofficial ‘BMF’ (Baddest Motherfucker) belt. But UFC fighters have never fit neatly into categories. They’re more diverse than previous generations, more likely to be non-white, non- LGBTQ+ or any other group that may feel aggrieved by the presidency. We’ve already seen that one day, Donald Trump will be out of office, and those MMA fans – and those who are not – will reclaim their place in “bro culture”

title: Freedom and joy: Rugby World Cup’s quirky quality sets it apart from the pack
summary: The Women’s Rugby World Cup has been one of largely lopsided scorelines, from the group stages to the quarter-finals. Only five of the 28 fixtures have been decided by fewer than 14 points, and more than half were won by more than 40 – at least six scores. But there remains a profound and unanimous pleasure to be had across the entire affair: it’'s hard to find anyone that's watching along and not enjoying it. Even as it has taken its slickly commercialised place in a crammed calendar of sporting events, this seems still fuelled by a radiant and irressible delight. Plenty of stadiums work hard to create a party atmosphere but you don’t get the sense here that anyone is forcing it or faking it when players are taking their positions before kick-off. Other sports – and their investors – will be analysing this fan engagement and wondering how to replicate it. Good luck to the South African No 8s.

title: The USTA’s censorship of Trump dissent at the US Open is cowardly, hypocritical and un-American
summary: The USTA has asked broadcasters not to show dissent against Donald Trump. The governing body has committed an unforced error that can’t be undone, says Julian Zelizer. Zelizer: The USTA isn’s just shielding Trump. It is stripping the event of its unique character, authenticity and integrity. The Open is supposed to be New York’S tournament, brash and democratic, rowdy and unfiltered, Zelizer says, where the crowd is as much a presence as the players on the court. It was the first of the majors to award equal prize money to women and men, and embraced and celebrated LGBTQ athletes decades before it was fashionable to do so in the 1970s and 80s. The US Open is literally building a path for generations of Black players who followed the story of Melissa Koby, who became the first Black player to compete at the US Open in 1950. And this year, the theme, “75 years of breaking barriers,” honors Althea Gibson, who broke barriers in 1950 to become the first African-American woman to compete in tennis.

title: I played in the NFL. Outrage over male cheerleaders is really about attempts to control masculinity
summary: The Minnesota Vikings unveiled their newly minted 35-member cheerleading squad. Two male performers, Blaize Shiek and Louie Conn, were part of the group. Almost immediately, reactions erupted online, from heartfelt support to calls for a boycott. As of the 2025 season, at least 11 NFL teams include male cheerleaders on their official squads, the first being the Los Angeles Rams back in 2018, when Quinton Peron and Napoleon Jinnies made history on the sidelines and later performed at the Super Bowl in 2019. The outrage over male cheerleader isn’t about sports. It’s about control: over masculinity, over image, and over who gets to be seen and celebrated in public spaces or on the global stage of the NFL. They’re cheering for the next generation, for the possibility of the possibility, of brotherhood and vulnerability.

title: ‘My time in the sun’: Rory McIlroy on Ryder Cup hopes and Masters glory
summary: Rory McIlroy is confident Europe can retain the Ryder Cup in 2023. The Northern Irishman is the sixth man in history to complete a career grand slam. The 25-year-old says he is more confident than he was at Hazeltine in 2016. He believes Europe are in a better spot than they were at Medinah in 2012. McIlory says he would love to win an away Ryder Cup at Bethpage in New York. He also believes the event would benefit from even the occasional away success. The Masters in April will serve as the reference point for this and so many other golfing years, regardless of whether or not Luke Donald and co can topple Keegan Bradley’s USA. The tribal nature of a non-tribal sport triggers strange things, says Mc Ilroy. “It is not as if any of this is preitated. It might not involve me but it is inevitable, whether like in last time or something else,” he says.

title: Trump’s strongman image got boos at the US Open, and perhaps that was the point
summary: Donald Trump's presence at the US Open men’s final wasn’t just intended as a soft power grab, the kind of routine stunt Vladimir Putin, Kim Jong-un and the other despots he admires pull all the time at sports events. The president smirked at the negative reaction. It surely rang so familiar. If Trump was motivated by a patriotic love for tennis, he would have rocked up a day earlier for the women's final. But for Trump the prospect of cheering on Jersey girl Amanda Anisimova and her epic comeback story clearly wasn't juicy enough, much less the idea of actually sharing the spotlight with an American player. Former presidents have shown that you can appear at a US Open without making it about ego: the Obamas were clearly caught up in supporting a US player when they watched Frances Tiafoe battle Alcaraz in the 2022 semi-final. “For me, playing in front of him, I don't want myself to be nervous,” said Spaniard Carlos Al Carcaraz, who stepped right into the trap.

title: NFL 2025 season predictions: will it be Mahomes, Jackson or Allen in the Super Bowl?
summary: Micah Parsons is a one-of-a-kind pass-rushing force, capable of detonating the pocket from any alignment. The Vikings managed a 14-3 regular-season record in the brutal NFC North last year, but they did on the back of Sam Darnold’s unpredictably great season. Despite having a 24-year-old quarterback, the Commanders have the oldest roster since 2012. Six quarterbacks (Daniels, Michael Penix Jr, CJ Stroud, Brock Purdy, Bo Nix and JJ McCarthy) 25 or under will start for teams that are likely to be in playoff contention. The Bears used their first three picks this year on offensive players. Look for Chicago to start gelling as the season goes on, before the brutal trifecta of the Packers, 49ers, and Lions in the Bears’ final three games sees them fall just short of the postseason. First-down technology is here, the chain gang merely standing idle to measure the distance in case their robot overlords fail.

title: The biggest takeaway from Izak Rankine’s case is to remember why these rules exist at all
summary: The flinch response to Izak Rankine’s homophobic slur was the sheer stupidity of it. Part of the problem here is that the AFL has forfeited much of the moral high ground. Many prominent football people seem reluctant to vocalise what they really think on this issue. There are gay men commentating games, running clubs, breaking stories and winning premierships. And still, not a single footballer has come out publicly. Rankine isn’t the first footballer to make a monumental mistake and miss an opportunity to win a premiership. The preternaturally talented and volcanic Phil Carman whacked Michael Tuck and probably cost his team a flag. If Adelaide wins the premiership, Rankine could say similar. And he may yet pay the price.

title: NFL preseason storylines: Cowboys chaos, the Browns‘ QB circus and Aaron Rodgers’ last dance
